content:
Yes, I believe that the COVID-19 pandemic had a bigger impact on the global economy than the trade dispute between the US and China. The pandemic caused unprecedented disruptions across the world, affecting almost all sectors of the economy, whereas the trade dispute primarily impacted trade flows between the US and China.

The COVID-19 pandemic caused widespread shutdowns of businesses and factories, leading to a global recession. Many industries such as tourism, hospitality, and aviation were particularly hard hit, resulting in massive job losses and bankruptcies. Governments had to launch significant stimulus packages to support individuals and businesses that had been affected by the pandemic, which had an impact on their fiscal position.

On the other hand, the US-China trade dispute impacted specific sectors such as agriculture, steel, and technology, and caused higher costs for businesses and consumers. However, overall, the impact on the global economy was not as severe as the pandemic. Additionally, the trade deal signed in December 2019 provided some relief to businesses and investors.

In conclusion, while both the pandemic and the US-China trade dispute impacted the global economy, the COVID-19 pandemic was more significant in terms of its widespread impact across all sectors of the economy, and its resulting impact on global growth and employment.
